facts.text: The respondent is a company registered under the Indian Companies Act, 1913, carrying on business in cotton.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent is a companypany registered under the Indian Companies Act, 1913, and is carrying on business in companyton.

facts.text: The respondent has head office in Bombay and maintains a branch at Karachi for purchasing cotton for shipment to Bombay or export.

anchor.surface_text: Its head office is in BOmbay, and it maintains a branch at Karachi of purchasing companyton for shipment to Bombay or export direct to other places.

facts.text: Separate accounts are maintained and separate profit and loss statements are prepared for Bombay and Karachi businesses.

anchor.surface_text: Separate accents are maintained and separate profit and loss statements are prepared for the business at Bombay and at Karachi.

facts.text: There is an agreement dated 22nd December appointing managing agents with clause 4 fixing remuneration at 20 per cent of net annual profits.

anchor.surface_text: BY an agreement dated 22nd December Ltd., as its managing agents, and under clause 4 of the agreement, the remuneration payable to them was fixed at 20 per cent. Of the net annul profits.

facts.text: During accounting year 1st October 1947 to 30th September 1948, respondent made total profit of Rs. 15,63,504.

anchor.surface_text: During the accounting year 1st October, 1947, to 30th September, 1948, the respondent made a total profit of Rs. 15,63,504, of which Rs. 9,44,905 was earned

facts.text: Out of total profit, Rs. 9,44,905 earned at Bombay and Rs. 6,18,599 at Karachi.

anchor.surface_text: of which Rs. 9,44,905 was earned in the business at Bombay and Rs. 6,18,599 at Karachi. On this, the companymission payable to the managing agents as per clause 4

facts.text: Commission payable to managing agents was Rs. 3,12,699.

anchor.surface_text: On this, the companymission payable to the managing agents as per clause 4 of the agreement was Rs. 3,12,699. The respondent debited a sum of Rs. 1,88,980 out

facts.text: Respondent debited Rs. 1,88,980 to Bombay profit and loss, showing net profits Rs. 7,55,925.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent debited a sum of Rs. 1,88,980 out of this amount in the profit and loss statement of the Bombay head office, being the 20 apportionable to the profits shown there in, and deducting this sum of the total profits of Rs. 9,44,905 showed a sum of Rs. 7,55,925 as the net profits of the business of Bombay.

facts.text: Respondent debited Rs. 1,23,719 to Karachi profit and loss, showing net profits Rs. 4,94,879.

anchor.surface_text: It likewise debited a sum of Rs. 1,23,719 to the profit and a loss statement of the Karachi branch, and deducting it out of the total profits of Rs. 6,18,599 earned by the branch, showed a sum of Rs. 4,94,879 as its net profits.

facts.text: The respondent is resident and ordinarily resident in India, chargeable to income tax on total world income.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent is resident and ordinarily resident in India,. and therefore it would be chargeable to in companye tax its total world income. Accordingly, the Income tax office took into the account profits earned both in India nd in Karachi

facts.text: Income Tax Officer determined total income at Rs. 13,09,375 after deducting entire commission.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, the Income tax office took into the account profits earned both in India nd in Karachi deducted therefrom the entire companymission paid to the managing agents, and after making certain adjustment, which are number material for the present purpose, determined the total income at Rs. 13,09,375.

facts.text: Correctness of total income figure Rs. 13,09,375 not in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: The companyrectness of this figure is number number in dispute.

facts.text: Notification issued on 10th December 1947 providing relief against double taxation with Pakistan.

anchor.surface_text: And in exercise of the powers companyferred under this sectarian. a numberification was issued on the 10th December, 1947., providing for relief being granted against double taxation of income in the manner and to the extent provided therein.

facts.text: Income Tax Officer accepted Rs. 4,94,879 as net profits of Karachi for double taxation relief calculation, held entitled to abatement of Rs. 5,00,344.

anchor.surface_text: For this purpose, he accepted as c companyrect the sum of Rs. 4,94,879 which the respondent had shown as the net profits in the profits and loss statement for karachi, and after making certain adjustment and deductions in accordance with clause 4 of the agreement and item 7  a  in the schedule annexed thereto, held that the amount in respect of which the respondent was entitled to abatement under the agreement was Rs. 5,00344.

facts.text: Assessee appealed to Appellate Assistant Commissioner contending ITO erred in taking net Rs. 4,94,879 instead of gross Rs. 6,18,599 for Karachi profits.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee preferred to an appeal against this order to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, and companytended that the Income Tax Officer was in error in taking Rs. 4,94,879 given in the profits and loss statement for Karachi as the profits of the Karachi branch, because this figure had been arrived at after the deducting a sum of Rs. 1,23,719 being the proportionate of the amount of the managing agency companymission but that the whole of it was payable at Bombay and was debatable to the head office, and that accordingly, the sum of Rs, 6,18,599 should have been taken as the profits of the branch and number Rs. 4,94,879.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner confirmed ITO order.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner disagreed with this companytention, a nd companyfirmed the order of the Income Tax offer.

facts.text: Tribunal held entire commission payable at Bombay, no portion debited to Karachi branch, allowed appeal to that extent.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent took the matter in appeal to the Tribunal, which held that the terms of the managing agency agreement, the entire companymission was payable at bombay, and that the accordingly numberportion of it should be debited to the Karachi branch. In the result the appeal was to that the extent allowed.

facts.text: On application of Commissioner, Tribunal referred question to High Court: whether Rs. 1,23,719 allowable as deduction against Indian profits.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon, on the application of the Commissioner, the Tribunal referred the following question for the decision of the High Court. Whether on the fact and in the circumstance of the case, the amount of Rs. 1,23,719 paid to the managing agents as companymission at 20 of the net profits of the Karachi branch, is allowable as a revenue deduction against the Indian profits of the assess companypany for the year of account ?

facts.text: High Court (Chagla CJ and Tendolkar J) answered reference in affirmative, following Birla Brothers Ltd. v. CIT.

anchor.surface_text: This reference was heard by Chagla, C.J. and Tendolkar, J. ... But they held following the decision in Birla Brothers Ltd. V. Commissioner of Income tax the hanging agency companymission should in its entirely be debited to the BOMBAY branch, even though the duty of the managing agents lay part in Karachi, and accordingly answered the reference in the affirmative.

facts.text: High Court granted certificate under section 66A for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: They, however, granted a certificate under section 66-A of the income TAx Act to appeal to this companyrt. That is how the Appeal companyes before us.

facts.text: Income Tax authorities in Pakistan originally admitted the deduction of Rs. 1,23,719 but later revised assessment and disallowed it.

anchor.surface_text: in fact, the Income Tax authorities in Pakistan who had originally admitted the deduction on the basis of the profits and loss statement had subsequently revised the assessment on the ground of error, and the had disallowed it.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that Rs. 1,23,719 is allowable as deduction against Indian profits.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent is therefore clearly entitled to the managing agents including the sum of Rs. 1,23,719 against the Indian profits.

issues.text: The question that arises for decision in this appeal is whether sum of Rs. 1,23,719 paid by the respondent as commission to its managing agents on amount of profits of its Karachi branch can be allowed as deduction against the Indian profits.

anchor.surface_text: The question that arises for decision in this appeal is whether sum of Rs. 1,23,719 paid by the respondent as companymission to its making agents on amount of profits of its Karachi branch can be allowed as deduction against the Indian profits.

issues.text: Whether on the fact and in the circumstance of the case, the amount of Rs. 1,23,719 paid to the managing agents as commission at 20% of the net profits of the Karachi branch, is allowable as a revenue deduction against the Indian profits of the assessee company for the year of account?

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon, on the application of the Commissioner, the Tribunal referred the following question for the decision of the High Court. Whether on the fact and in the circumstance of the case, the amount of Rs. 1,23,719 paid to the managing agents as companymission at 20 of the net profits of the Karachi branch, is allowable as a revenue deduction against the Indian profits of the assess companypany for the year of account ?

issues.text: What has therefore to be determined is whether, notwithstanding the apportionment made by the respondent in the profits and loss statement, the deduction is admissible under the law.

issues.text: When an assessee carries on the same business at a number of places, there is for the purpose of section 10, only one business, and the net profits of the business have to be ascertained after deducting all the expenses.

anchor.surface_text: Now, the respondent is carrying on business in companyton both in India and In Karachi. When an assessee carries on the same business at a number of places, there is for the purpose of section 10, only one business, and the net profits of the business have to be ascertained therefrom all the expenses.

arguments.claim: Income Tax Officer erred in taking Rs. 4,94,879 as net profits of Karachi branch after deducting proportionate commission; correct figure is gross Rs. 6,18,599 as whole commission payable at Bombay and debitable only to head office.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee preferred to an appeal against this order to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, and contended that the Income Tax Officer was in error in taking Rs. 4,94,879 given in the profits and loss statement for Karachi as the profits of the Karachi branch, because this figure had been arrived at after deducting a sum of Rs. 1,23,719 being the proportionate of the amount of the managing agency commission but that the whole of it was payable at Bombay and was debitable to the head office, and that accordingly, the sum of Rs, 6,18,599 should have been taken as the profits of the branch and not Rs. 4,94,879.

arguments.court_reasoning: Commission allowable against Indian profits as part of total business expenses.

arguments.claim: Deducting Rs. 1,23,719 against Indian profits gives double relief as entire commission already deducted from total income before allocating net profits to branches.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the Appellant, the learned Solicitor General contended that the sum of Rs. 1,23,719 could not be added to the sum of Rs. 4,94,879 as the profits assessable to income tax in Pakistan, because the entire commission of Rs. 3,12,699 due under the agreement had been deducted out of the Rs. 15,63,504 the total income of the assessee, and it was only the net income of Rs. 12,50,804 that had been allocated Rs. 7,55,925 for the business at Bombay and Rs. 4,94,879 for the Karachi business, and that to disallow Rs. 1,23,719 which had been included in the profits and loss statement of Pakistan would be to give relief twice over in respect of the same income.

arguments.claim: Assessee not entitled to deduction against Indian profits as it itself deducted Rs. 1,23,719 from Karachi profits in P&L and obtained relief in Pakistan on that basis.

arguments.claim: Assessee estopped from claiming deduction against Indian profits as it split commission and allocated Rs. 1,23,719 to Karachi profits in its own accounts.

anchor.surface_text: On the question of the admissibility of the deduction of Rs. 1,23.719 the contention of the appellant is that as the respondent had itself split up the commission of Rs. 3,12,699 paid to the managing agents, and appropriated Rs. 1,23,719 thereof to the profits earned at Karachi and had debited the same with it, it was not entitled to go back upon it. and claim the amount as a deduction against the Indian profits.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: n the view, which it might the take of its rights and companysequently, if the whole of the companymission is under the law liable to the deducted aga

arguments.court_reasoning: Entitlement depends on law, not assessee's view of its rights.

arguments.claim: No estoppel from assessee's erroneous allocation; deduction entitlement determined by law, not accounting treatment.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the respondent is entitled to the particular deduction or not will depend on the provision of law relating thereto and not on the view which it might take of its rights and consequently, if the whole of the commission is under the law liable to be deducted against the Indian profits, the respondent cannot be estoppel from claiming the benefit of such deduction, by reason of the fact that it erroneously allocated a part of it towards the profits earned in Karachi.

arguments.claim: Rs. 1,23,719 commission allowable as deduction under Section 10(2)(xv) against total Indian profits; single integrated business across locations including foreign branches for resident assessee.

anchor.surface_text: Section 10  2   XV  of the Indian Income TAx Act provided that in computing the profits of a business, allowances is to be made for any expenditure laid out or expended wholly and exclusively for the purpose of such business. Now, the respondent is carrying on business in cotton both in India and In Karachi. When an assessee carries on the same business at a number of places, there is for the purpose of section 10, only one business, and the net profits of the business have to be ascertained therefrom all the expenses.

arguments.claim: Apportionment of Rs. 1,23,719 commission to Karachi branch not warranted by managing agency agreement terms; commission on net profits of company as whole considering all branches.

anchor.surface_text: It should further be added that the apportionment of the Rs. 1,23,719 in the profit and loss statement of the on Which the appellant rests his argument is not warranted by the terms of the managing agency agreement, and is indeed opposed to them. Under that the agreement, the managing agents are entitled to a 20 commission on the annual net profits of the company. and to ascertain those profits one had to take into account the result of the trade in all its branches.

holdings.text: The sum of Rs. 1,23,719 paid as commission to managing agents on profits of Karachi branch is allowable as a deduction against the Indian profits.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, the profits earned in India and in Karachi have to be thrown together, and the expenses including the companymissions payable to the managing agents deducted therefrom, and it is the net profits thus struck that become chargeable under the Act. That is how the Income tax Officer had worked out the figure. The respondent is therefore clearly entitled to the managing agents including the sum of Rs. 1,23,719 against the Indian profits.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Under Section 10(2)(xv), commission is allowable expenditure wholly for business; resident assessee's cotton business at Bombay and Karachi constitutes single integrated business; all expenses deducted from total world profits before determining taxable net profits.

holdings.text: The respondent cannot be estopped from claiming deduction of Rs. 1,23,719 against Indian profits merely because it erroneously apportioned part of commission to Karachi branch in its accounts.

anchor.surface_text: We do number see any force in this companytention. Whether the respondent is entitled to the particular deduction or number will dependent on the provision of law relating thereto and number on the view, which it might the take of its rights and companysequently, if the whole of the companymission is under the law liable to the deducted against the Indian profits, the respondent cannot be estoppel from claiming the benefit of such deduction, by reason of the fact that it erroneously allocated a part of it towards the profits earned in Karachi. What has therefore to be determined is whether, numberwithstanding the apportionment made by and the respondent in the profits and loss statement, the deduction is admissible under the law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Entitlement to statutory deduction depends solely on legal provisions, not assessee's mistaken view or accounting allocation.

holdings.text: An assessee carrying on the same business at multiple places, including foreign branches, has only one business for Section 10 purposes; net profits ascertained after deducting all expenses from aggregated profits.

anchor.surface_text: Section 10  2   XV  of the Indian Income TAx Act provided that in companyputing the profits of a business, allowances is to be made for any expenditure laid out or expended wholly and exclusively for the purpose of such business. Now, the respondent is carrying on business in companyton both in India and In Karachi. When an assessee carries on the same business at a number of places, there is for the purpose of section 10, only one business, and the net profits of the business have to be ascertained therefrom all the expenses. The fact that same of the branches are in foreign territories will make numberdifference in the position, if the assessee is as, in the present case, resident and ordinarily resident within the taxable territories.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Profits from all branches pooled; expenses like managing commission deducted centrally regardless of location; applies to resident with foreign branches.

holdings.text: Apportionment of Rs. 1,23,719 commission to Karachi branch profits is not warranted by and opposed to managing agency agreement terms.

anchor.surface_text: It should further be added that the apportionment of the Rs. 1,23,719 in the profit and loss statement of the on Which the appellant rests his argument is number warranted by the terms of the managing agency agreement, and is indeed opposed to them. Under that the agreement, the managing agents are entitled to a 20 companymission on the annual net profits of the companypany. and to the ascerta those profits one had to take into account the result of the trade in all its branches.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agreement provides 20% commission on company's annual net profits as whole (all branches); branch-wise apportionment ignores set-off possibilities between profitable and loss-making branches.

anchor.surface_text: Section 10  2   XV  of the Indian Income TAx Act provided that in companyputing the profits of a business, allowances is to be made for any expenditure laid out or expended wholly and exclusively for the purpose of such business. Now, the respondent is carrying on business in companyton both in India and In Karachi. When an assessee carries on the same business at a number of places, there is for the purpose of section 10, only one business, and the net profits of the business have to be ascertained therefrom all the expenses. The fact that same of the branches are in foreign territories will make numberdifference in the position, if the assessee is as, in the present case, resident and ordinarily resident within the taxable territories.
The respondent is therefore clearly entitled to the managing agency commission including the sum of Rs. 1,23,719 against the Indian profits.
